definitions.definition: to remove fat, cream, etc. from the surface of a liquid

examples.text: Skim the scum off the jam and let it cool.
Skim the jam and let it cool.

definitions.definition: to move quickly and lightly over a surface, not touching it or only touching it occasionally; to make something do this
definitions.sensetop: skim along/over, etc. somethingskim somethingskim something across, over, etc. something

examples.text: We watched the birds skimming over the lake.
We skimmed across the water in a small sailing boat.
His eyes skimmed over her face.
The speedboat took off, skimming the waves.
This report has barely **skimmed the surface** of the subject.
Small boys were skimming stones across the water.
examples.contextForm: skim something across, over, etc. something

definitions.definition: to read something quickly in order to find a particular point or the main points

examples.text: He skimmed through the article trying to find his name.
I always skim the financial section of the newspaper.
I skimmed the list until I found my name.

definitions.definition: to steal small amounts of money frequently over a period of time

examples.text: She’d been skimming money from the store’s accounts for years.

definitions.definition: to illegally copy electronic information from a credit card in order to use it without the owner’s permission

examples.text: It is estimated that skimming now accounts for almost 50% of credit card fraud.

wordOrigin: Middle English (in the sense ‘remove scum from (a liquid)’): back-formation from skimmer, or from Old French escumer, from escume ‘scum, foam’.
